metadata.case_name: K. Joseph Augusthi & Ors. v. Official Liquidator, Palai Central Bank Ltd.

facts.text: K. Joseph Augusthi was the Managing Director of the Palai Central Bank Limited from 26-1-1927 to 8-8-1960.
George Thomas was a Director of the Palai Central Bank Limited from 14-1-1935 to 8-8-1960.
George Joseph was a Director of the Palai Central Bank Limited from 26-1-1927 to 8-8-1960.

An application for winding up of the Palai Central Bank Limited was made by the Reserve Bank before the Kerala High Court under section 38(3)(b)(iii) of the Banking Companies Act, 1949, as continuance was prejudicial to depositors.
On 8th August 1960, the Kerala High Court appointed the Official Liquidator as Provisional Liquidator.
Winding up order passed on 5th December 1960.
Official Liquidator appointed under s.39 on 8th December 1960.
Official Liquidator submitted report No.192 on 17th August 1961 under s.45G(1), stating loss caused by acts/omissions of directors and auditor.
Official Liquidator submitted report No.242 on 29th September 1961 under s.45G(1).
Appellants filed objections on 23rd November 1961 to the first two reports.
Official Liquidator submitted report No.350 on 4th December 1961 under s.45G(1).
Single Judge of Kerala High Court directed public examination of the three appellants under s.45G(2).
Division Bench of Kerala High Court dismissed appeals against single Judge's order.
High Court granted certificates for appeal to Supreme Court.

Liquidator's reports alleged: loans advanced without adequate security, many unsecured and time-barred; dividends paid without earning profits; profits declared 1936-1958 without earning, income-tax paid thereon; large irrecoverable advances.
Liquidator named 10 persons including appellants as responsible for loss.

Appellant Joseph Augusthi admitted using mercantile system of accounting: treating accrued interest as income for dividends and taxes, despite not received; claimed Reserve Bank noticed and waived objection.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 45G of the Banking Companies Act, 1949 is unconstitutional as it contravenes Article 20(3) of the Constitution.
What is the true scope and effect of section 45G, particularly whether acts/omissions must be prohibited by law or enjoined, and whether proviso to s.45G(2) was complied with.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 45G is unconstitutional as it contravenes Art.20(3) by compelling persons to be witnesses against themselves via public examination.
High Court misconstrued s.45G: acts/omissions must be those prohibited by law or where performance enjoined by law; reports do not disclose such.
No opportunity given under proviso to s.45G(2) to show cause why public examination should not be ordered; full hearing required before ordering.

court_reasoning.text: s.45G does not violate Art.20(3) because at the time of ordering public examination, no person is 'accused of any offence'; examination is preliminary inquiry to collect evidence, accusation may follow later but is not pre-existing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accusation of offence is condition precedent for Art.20(3); lacking in s.45G proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: Scope of s.45G(1): acts/omissions causing loss to bank since formation, need not be fraudulent, criminal, or illegal; may include commercially unsound acts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unlike s.478 Companies Act or English s.268 requiring fraud.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso to s.45G(2) satisfied by prima facie consideration of liquidator's report, hearing explanation; not full trial on merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preliminary stage: assess if reasonable opinion for examination just and beneficial to bank.

court_reasoning.text: Reports disclose specific acts/omissions causing loss; appellants' objections considered prima facie insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Allegations clear, precise; some facts admitted.

holdings.text: Section 45G constitutional, does not contravene Art.20(3).
s.45G covers any acts/omissions causing loss, not limited to illegal/fraudulent; proviso requires only prima facie opportunity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mallala Suryanarayana v. The Vijaya Commercial Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.citation: Civil Appeal No. 286 of 1959, A.I.R. 1961 S.C. 29
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.45G does not contravene Art.20(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck Phiroz Mistry
precedents_cited.relevance: s.240 old Companies Act does not contravene Art.20(3).
Required finding of fraud under English s.8(3); unlike s.45G(1) which does not require fraud.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sir Fazal Ibrahim Rahimtoola v. Appabhai C. Desai
precedents_cited.relevance: Disapproved ex parte public examinations under old s.196; allegations here not vague.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ahmedabad Advance Spinning and Weaving Company v. Lakshmishanker
precedents_cited.relevance: Deprecates ex parte orders for public examination.

statutes_cited.name: Banking Companies Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs winding up, liquidator reports, public examination of directors/auditors for acts causing loss.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Protection against compelled self-incrimination for accused persons; not violated by s.45G.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Compared: s.478/268 English require fraud unlike s.45G.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upheld Kerala High Court orders for public examination under s.45G, holding section constitutional and properly applied on prima facie basis after considering reports and objections.

key_quotes.text: "Article 20(3) guarantees to every citizen the fundamental right not to be compelled to be a witness against himself, provided the person who is being compelled in that way, is accused of any offence."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The acts or omissions to which s.45G(1) refers need not be fraudulent acts or omissions, because, in terms, the section provides that the act or omission would attract s.45G(1) if it has led to any loss."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "What the Court can and should do... is to read the report... consider whether the opinion... appears to be, prima facie, reasonable hear the explanation... and find out prima facie whether the explanation... is sufficient."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains compliance with proviso to s.45G(2).
